messages.subject: Re: [samuraihistory] Re: Gatling-----some history Prof Murf
messages.msgSnippet: The gatling gun was not used until later int he war bcos of supposed confederate sympathies by Gatling... thats why it was adopted several years later and you
messages.messageBody:
The gatling gun was not used until later int he war bcos of supposed confederate sympathies by Gatling... thats why it was adopted several years later and you see uses of it ont he battle field later, but domestic uses earlier..

Wilson


--

--------- Original Message ---------
DATE: Thu, 15 Jan 2004 00:19:30
From: burker1@...
To: samuraihistory@yahoogroups.com
Cc:

I remember reading that the first use of the Gatling gun was during the NY
Draft Riots in 1863. But perhaps Prof Murphy was referring to its first use on
the battlefield?

Bob Burke


In a message dated 1/14/04 1:07:11 AM, murphymurphyjohn@... writes:

<< The Gatling gun was apparently first used at Petersburg, VA, in the
American
Civil War in 1864-5. It was formally adopted in 1866 by the US Army.
Indeed,
one of the factors that brought about Custer's disastrous defeat in 1876 was
that he apparently disdained to bring along a Gatling gun detachment because
it would slow him up! Thus, it is entirely possible that a friendly
country
like Meiji Japan could have been shipped some by the 1877 rebellion. Prof
Murf >>

messages.subject: Re: [samuraihistory] Re: Gatling-----some history Prof Murf
messages.msgSnippet: The Gatling gun was apparently first used at Petersburg, VA, in the American Civil War in 1864-5.  It was formally adopted in 1866 by the US Army.  Indeed, one
messages.messageBody:
The Gatling gun was apparently first used at Petersburg, VA, in the American
Civil War in 1864-5. It was formally adopted in 1866 by the US Army. Indeed,
one of the factors that brought about Custer's disastrous defeat in 1876 was
that he apparently disdained to bring along a Gatling gun detachment because
it would slow him up! Thus, it is entirely possible that a friendly country
like Meiji Japan could have been shipped some by the 1877 rebellion. Prof Murf



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
